p^{T+1}\left(\pi_{j}^{T+1}=\pi_{j}^{T} \cup\{T+1\} \mid \pi^{T}\right)=f\left(\left|\pi_{j}^{T}\right|, T\right)
$$

(D) For $T \geq 1$ and $\pi^{T} \in \Pi^{T}$,

$$
p^{T+1}\left(\pi^{T+1}(T+1)=\{T+1\} \mid \pi^{T}\right)=g\left(\left|\pi^{T}\right|, T\right)
$$

Lemma 1 (Zabell, 1997) Conditions (A) to (D) imply that there exist $\alpha$ and $\theta$ with $\alpha \in[0,1)$ and $\theta>-\alpha$ such that

$$
\begin{aligned}
f\left(\left|\pi_{j}^{T}\right|, T\right) & =\frac{\left|\pi_{j}^{T}\right|-\alpha}{T+\theta} \\
g\left(\left|\pi^{T}\right|, T\right) & =\frac{\alpha\left|\pi^{T}\right|+\theta}{T+\theta}
\end{aligned}
$$

We continue with the proof of Theorem 1. First, we consider direction " $\Rightarrow$ ". We verify conditions (A) to (D).

Condition (A): By Assumption 1, $\succeq$ has a countable additive subjective expected utility representation. Denote by $\mu$ the associated probability measure. For any $T$ and $\pi^{T} \in \Pi^{T}$, let $p^{T}\left(\pi^{T}\right):=\mu\left(\left|\pi^{T}\right|\right)$. This defines a probability in $\Delta\left(\Pi^{T}\right)$. We claim that for all $T$ and $T^{\prime} \leq T$, $\pi^{T^{\prime}} \in \Pi^{T^{\prime}}$,

$$
\mu\left(\left[\left(\rho_{T^{\prime}}^{T}\right)^{-1}\left(\pi^{T^{\prime}}\right)\right]\right)=\mu\left(\left[\pi^{T^{\prime}}\right]\right)
$$

Note that $\left[\left(\rho_{T^{\prime}}^{T}\right)^{-1}\left(\pi^{T^{\prime}}\right)\right]$ is measurable because it is a finite union of measurable events, i.e., $\left[\left(\rho_{T^{\prime}}^{T}\right)^{-1}\left(\pi^{T^{\prime}}\right)\right]=\bigcup_{\pi^{T} \in\left(\rho_{T^{\prime}}^{T}\right)^{-1}\left(\pi^{T^{\prime}}\right)}\left[\pi^{T}\right]$.

We will show $\left[\left(\rho_{T^{\prime}}^{T}\right)^{-1}\left(\pi^{T^{\prime}}\right)\right]=\left[\pi^{T^{\prime}}\right]$.
Consider the case " $\supseteq$ ": For any $\omega \in\left[\pi^{T^{\prime}}\right], \pi^{T^{\prime}}(\omega)=\pi^{T^{\prime}}$. By the partition functions $\left(\pi^{T}\right)_{T=1,2, \ldots}$ satisfy consistency, we have $\pi^{T}(\omega)_{\mid T^{\prime}}=\pi^{T^{\prime}}(\omega)$. Since $\pi^{T}$ is a function with codomain $\Pi^{T}$, there exist $\pi^{T} \in \Pi^{T}$ such that $\pi^{T}(\omega)=\pi^{T}$. This is the case if and only if $\omega \in$ $\left[\pi^{T}\right]$. Consistency of $\left(\pi^{T}\right)_{T=1,2, \ldots}$ implies that $\pi^{T} \in\left(\rho_{T^{\prime}}^{T}\right)^{-1}\left(\pi^{T^{\prime}}\right)$. Thus, $\omega \in\left[\left(\rho_{T^{\prime}}^{T}\right)^{-1}\left(\pi^{T^{\prime}}\right)\right]$.

Next consider the case " $\subseteq$ ": Let $\omega \in\left[\left(\rho_{T^{\prime}}^{T}\right)^{-1}\left(\pi^{T^{\prime}}\right)\right]$ implies $\omega \in\left[\pi^{T}\right]$ for some $\pi^{T} \in$ $\left(\rho_{T^{\prime}}^{T}\right)^{-1}\left(\pi^{T^{\prime}}\right)$. Observe that $\omega \in\left[\pi^{T}\right]$ if and only if $\pi^{T}(\omega)=\pi^{T}$. Since partition functions $\left(\pi^{T}\right)_{T=1,2, \ldots}$ satisfy consistency, $\pi^{T}(\omega)_{\mid T^{\prime}}=\pi^{T^{\prime}}(\omega)$. Since $\pi^{T} \in\left(\rho_{T^{\prime}}^{T}\right)^{-1}\left(\pi^{T^{\prime}}\right), \pi^{T^{\prime}}(\omega)=\pi^{T^{\prime}}$. Thus, $\omega \in\left[\pi^{T^{\prime}}\right]$.

It follows now that the collection of probability measures $\left(p^{T}\right)_{T \geq 1}$ is consistent. By Property 1 and Proposition 1, for $T \geq 1, p^{T}$ is partition exchangeable. By above arguments, there exists a unique extension $p^{\infty}$ that is infinite partition exchangeable. This verifies Condition (A).

Condition (B): Using Assumption 1, Property 2 implies Condition (B).
Condition (C): By Assumption 1, in the following we can conveniently normalize $u$ w.l.o.g. such that $u(0)=0$.

By Assumption 1, arguments analogous to the proof of Proposition 1 imply by Property 3 for all $T \geq 1, k \in\{1, \ldots T\}, \boldsymbol{\pi}^{T}, \tilde{\boldsymbol{\pi}}^{T} \in \Pi^{T, k}$,

$$
\mu\left(\left[\left|\pi^{T+1}(\cdot)(T+1)\right|=k+1\right] \mid\left[\boldsymbol{\pi}^{T}\right]\right)=\mu\left(\left[\left|\pi^{T+1}(\cdot)(T+1)\right|=k+1\right] \mid\left[\tilde{\boldsymbol{\pi}}^{T}\right]\right)
$$

Note that since $\boldsymbol{\pi}^{T} \in \Pi^{T, k}$, it must be that $\left[\left|\pi^{T+1}(\cdot)(T+1)\right|=k+1\right] \cap\left[\boldsymbol{\pi}^{T}\right]=$ $\left[\left|\pi_{j}^{T+1}(\cdot)\right|=\left|\pi_{j}^{T}(\cdot)\right|+1\right] \cap\left[\boldsymbol{\pi}^{T}\right]=\left[\pi_{j}^{T+1}(\cdot)=\pi_{j}^{T}(\cdot) \cup\{T+1\}\right] \cap\left[\boldsymbol{\pi}^{T}\right]$ for some $j \leq T$ with $\left|\boldsymbol{\pi}_{j}^{T}\right|=k$. Since this holds for any partition $\boldsymbol{\pi}^{T} \in \Pi^{T, k}$, we must have that

$$
\mu\left(\left[\left|\pi_{j}^{T+1}(\cdot)\right|=\left|\pi_{j}^{T}(\cdot)\right|+1\right] \mid\left[\boldsymbol{\pi}^{T}\right]\right)=f(k, T)
$$

for some function $f$ of $k$ and $T$. This verifies Condition (C).
For Condition (D), note that by Assumption 1 and arguments analogous to the proof of Proposition 1 we have by Property 4 that for $T \geq 1$ and $\boldsymbol{\pi}^{T}, \tilde{\boldsymbol{\pi}}^{T} \in \Pi^{T}$ with $\left|\boldsymbol{\pi}^{T}\right|=\left|\tilde{\boldsymbol{\pi}}^{T}\right|$,

$$
\mu\left(\left[\left|\pi^{T+1}(\cdot)(T+1)\right|=1\right] \mid\left[\boldsymbol{\pi}^{T}\right]\right)=\mu\left(\left[\left|\pi^{T+1}(\cdot)(T+1)\right|=1\right] \mid\left[\tilde{\boldsymbol{\pi}}^{T}\right]\right)
$$

Observe that $\left[\left|\pi^{T+1}(\cdot)(T+1)\right|=1\right] \cap\left[\boldsymbol{\pi}^{T}\right]=\left[\left|\pi^{T+1}(\cdot)\right|=\left|\pi^{T}(\cdot)\right|+1\right] \cap\left[\boldsymbol{\pi}^{T}\right]$ $=\left[\pi^{T+1}(\cdot)(T+1)=\{T+1\}\right] \cap\left[\boldsymbol{\pi}^{T}\right]$. Since this holds for any partition $\boldsymbol{\pi}^{T}, \tilde{\boldsymbol{\pi}}^{T} \in \Pi^{T}$ with $\left|\boldsymbol{\pi}^{T}\right|=\left|\tilde{\boldsymbol{\pi}}^{T}\right|$, it must be that

$$
\mu\left(\left[\left|\pi^{T+1}(\cdot)\right|=\left|\pi^{T}(\cdot)\right|+1\right] \mid\left[\boldsymbol{\pi}^{T}\right]\right)=g\left(\left|\boldsymbol{\pi}^{T}\right|, T\right)
$$

for some function $g$ of the cardinality of partition $\boldsymbol{\pi}^{T}$ and $T$. This verifies Condition (D).
It now follows from Lemma 1 that the partition-conditional subjective expected utility representation follows the prediction rule of Theorem 1.

Now consider direction " $\Leftarrow$ ". For any $T \geq 1$ and $\boldsymbol{\pi}^{T} \in \Pi^{T}$, define $\mu\left(\cdot \mid\left[\boldsymbol{\pi}^{T}\right]\right):=p^{T+1}\left(\cdot \mid \boldsymbol{\pi}^{T}\right)$. By Assumption 1 there exist a collection of partition conditional preferences $\left\{\sum_{\boldsymbol{\pi}^{T}}\right\}_{\boldsymbol{\pi}^{T} \in \Pi^{T}, T \geq 1}$.

Pitman (1995, Proposition 9) shows that the prediction rule implies equation (5). Assumption 1 implies now Property 1.

Property 2 is implied from the range of parameters of the prediction rule of Theorem 1 and Assumption 1. In particular, conditional on any partition, any previously encountered object has strict positive probability. A novel object has strict positive probability as well. Thus, ex ante no partition is ruled.

Reversing the arguments in the proof of Conditions (C) and (D) of the part " $\Rightarrow$ " above proves the necessity of Properties 3 and 4, respectively.

Finally, we show how to calibrate the parameters of the prediction rule from choices. Let $z \in \mathbb{R}$ be defined by the choice behavior $1_{[\{1\},\{2,3\},\{4\}\}]} 0 \sim_{\{\{1\},\{2,3\}\}} z$ and $k \in \mathbb{R}$ be defined by

choice behavior $1_{[\{\{1,4\},\{2,3\}\}]} 0 \sim_{\{\{1\},\{2,3\}\}} k$. We continue to assume that $u$ is normalized such that $u(0)=0$. By arguments similar to the proof of Proposition 1 we obtain

$$
\mu(\{\{1\},\{2,3\},\{4\}\} \mid\{\{1\},\{2,3\}\})=\frac{u(z)}{u(1)}
$$

and

$$
\mu(\{\{1,4\},\{2,3\}\} \mid\{\{1\},\{2,3\}\})=\frac{u(k)}{u(1)}
$$

Using the prediction rules of equations (1) and (2), respectively, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{u(k)}{u(1)}=\frac{1-\alpha}{3+\theta} \\
& \frac{u(z)}{u(1)}=\frac{2 \alpha+\theta}{3+\theta}
\end{aligned}
$$

Solving these two equations for $\alpha$ and $\theta$ yields the expressions in equations (3) and (4), respectively.

# Proof of Proposition 2 

We prove just the case for the two-parameter model. The other cases are direct corollaries. Since $\succeq_{\pi^{T}}$ has a subjective expected utility representation, choice

$$
(T+\theta)_{[\bullet]} 0 \sim_{\pi^{T}}\left(\alpha\left|\pi^{T}\right|+\theta\right)
$$

is equivalent to

$$
\int_{\Omega} u\left((T+\theta)_{[\bullet]} 0\right) d \mu\left(\cdot \mid \pi^{T}\right)=\int_{\Omega} u\left(\left(\alpha\left|\pi^{T}\right|+\theta\right)\right) d \mu\left(\cdot \mid \pi^{T}\right)
$$

Under risk neutrality we can chose $u(x)=x$. Thus, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{\Omega}(T+\theta)_{[\bullet]} 0 d \mu\left(\cdot \mid \pi^{T}\right) & =\int_{\Omega}\left(\alpha\left|\pi^{T}\right|+\theta\right) d \mu\left(\cdot \mid \pi^{T}\right) \\
(T+\theta) \mu([\bullet] \mid \pi^{T}) & =\left(\alpha\left|\pi^{T}\right|+\theta\right) \\
\mu([\bullet] \mid \pi^{T}) & =\frac{\alpha\left|\pi^{T}\right|+\theta}{T+\theta}
\end{aligned}
$$

The case

$$
(T+\theta)_{[j]} 0 \sim_{\pi^{T}}\left(\left|\pi_{j}^{T}\right|-\alpha\right)
$$

follows by analogous arguments.

# Proof of Proposition 3 

We prove part (i): Let $\left\{\succeq_{\pi^{T}} \succeq_{\pi^{T} \in \Pi^{T}, T \geq 1}\right.$ satisfy Assumption 1. Recall Property 6: for any $T$ and $\pi^{T} \in \Pi^{T}$ and $i, j \leq\left|\pi^{T}\right|$, there are $x, y \in \mathbb{R}$ such that

$$
x_{\left[T+1 \in \pi_{i}^{T+1}(\cdot)\right]}^{0 \sim_{\pi^{T}} y_{\left[T+1 \in \pi_{j}^{T+1}(\cdot)\right.}} \text { iff } \quad x_{\left[T+2 \in \pi_{i}^{T+2}(\cdot)\right]}^{0 \sim_{\pi^{T+1}} y_{\left[T+2 \in \pi_{j}^{T+2}(\cdot)\right.}} 0
$$

for $\pi^{T+1}=\pi^{T} \cup\{T+1\}$. By Assumption 1, the left-hand side is equivalent to

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\Omega} u\left(x_{\left[T+1 \in \pi_{i}^{T+1}(\cdot)\right]}^{0} 0\right) d \mu\left(\cdot \mid\left[\pi^{T}\right]\right)=\int_{\Omega} u\left(y_{\left[T+1 \in \pi_{j}^{T+1}(\cdot)\right]}^{0} 0\right) d \mu\left(\cdot \mid\left[\pi^{T}\right]\right) \\
& u(x) \mu\left(\left[T+1 \in \pi_{i}^{T+1}(\cdot)\right] \mid\left[\pi^{T}\right]\right)=u(y) \mu\left(\left[T+1 \in \pi_{j}^{T+1}(\cdot)\right] \mid\left[\pi^{T}\right]\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

By Property 2 and Assumption 1, probabilities must be nonzero. Thus, we can rewrite the equation as

$$
\frac{\mu\left(\left[T+1 \in \pi_{i}^{T+1}(\cdot)\right] \mid\left[\pi^{T}\right]\right)}{\mu\left(\left[T+1 \in \pi_{j}^{T+1}(\cdot)\right] \mid\left[\pi^{T}\right]\right)}=\frac{u(y)}{u(x)}
$$

By analogous arguments, the r.h.s. is equivalent to

$$
\frac{\mu\left(\left[T+2 \in \pi_{i}^{T+2}(\cdot)\right] \mid\left[\pi^{T+1}\right]\right)}{\mu\left(\left[T+2 \in \pi_{j}^{T+2}(\cdot)\right] \mid\left[\pi^{T+1}\right]\right)}=\frac{u(y)}{u(x)}
$$

"Reverse" Bayesianism now follows.
Parts (ii) and (iii) follow analogously by replacing Property 6 in above arguments with Property 7 or 8 , respectively.

## B SEU Representation

We the sake of completeness, we state the properties and theorem characterizing Assumption 1. We find it convenient to make use of Wakker (1989, Chapter V.5). Let $C$ be a nonempty connected separable topological space of outcomes or consequences endowed with the Borel $\sigma$-algebra $\Sigma_{C}$. For any outcomes $x, y \in C$, we let $x \forall y=x$ if $x \succeq y$ and $x \forall y=y$ otherwise. Similarly, $x \wedge y=x$ if $x \preceq y$ and $x \wedge y=y$ otherwise. For any act $f$ and consequence $x$, the above truncation is the act $f \forall x$ defined by $(f \forall x)(\omega)=f(\omega) \forall x$ for all $\omega \in \Omega$. Define analogously the below truncation. A set of acts is truncation closed w.r.t. $\succeq$ if for every act in that set and every consequence also the above truncation and below truncation is contained in that set. We say that an act $f$ is bounded w.r.t. $\succeq$ if there exist consequences $x, y \in C$ such that $x \succeq f \succeq y$.

We say that $\left\langle\left\langle\Omega, \Sigma_{\Omega}\right\rangle,\left\langle C, \Sigma_{C}\right\rangle, \mathcal{F}, \succeq\right\rangle$ is an abstract choice frame if $\mathcal{F}$ is the set of all measurable acts $f: \Omega \longrightarrow C$ that include the simple acts, are truncation closed w.r.t. $\succeq$, and are bounded w.r.t. $\succeq$. In the following we fix an abstract choice frame.

Property 9 (Weak order) $\succeq$ is a weak order, i.e., complete and transitive.

Property 10 (Pointwise monotonicity) $\succeq$ is pointwise monotone, i.e., for any $f, g \in \mathcal{F}$, $f(\omega) \succeq g(\omega)$ for all $\omega \in \Omega$ implies $f \succeq g$.

For event $E \in \Sigma_{\Omega}$ and consequences $x, y, z, w \in C$, we write

$$
x y \succeq^{E} z w
$$

if there exist simple acts $f, g \in \mathcal{F}$ such that $x_{E} f \succeq y_{E} g$ and $z_{E} f \preceq w_{E} g$. We write

$$
x y \triangleright^{E} z w
$$

if there exist simple acts $f, g \in \mathcal{F}$ such that $x_{E} f \succeq y_{E} g$ and $z_{E} f \nsubseteq w_{E} g$.
Property 11 (Event Tradeoff Consistency) There do not exist simple $\succeq$-non-null events $E, F \in \Sigma_{\Omega}$ and consequences $x, y, z, w \in C$ such that $x y \succeq^{E} z w$ and $z w \triangleright^{F} x y$.

For any partition $\left\{E_{i}\right\}_{i=1}^{m}$ of $\Omega$ and consequences $x^{1}, \ldots, x^{m} \in C$, denote by $x_{E_{1}}^{1} x_{E_{2}}^{2} \ldots x_{E_{m}}^{m}$ the composite act defined by $x_{E_{1}}^{1} x_{E_{2}}^{2} \ldots x_{E_{m}}^{m}(\omega)=x^{\ell}$ if $\omega \in E_{\ell}$.

Property 12 (Simple-continuity) $\succeq$ is simple-continuous if for any partition $\left\{E_{i}\right\}_{i=1}^{m}$ of $\Omega$ and simple act $f$ measurable w.r.t. $\left\{E_{i}\right\}_{i=1}^{m}$, the better set $\left\{\left(x^{1}, \ldots, x^{m}\right) \in C^{m}: x_{E_{1}}^{1} x_{E_{2}}^{2} \ldots x_{E_{m}}^{m} \succeq\right.$ $f\}$ and worse set $\left\{\left(x^{1}, \ldots, x^{m}\right) \in C^{m}: x_{E_{1}}^{1} x_{E_{2}}^{2} \ldots x_{E_{m}}^{m} \preceq f\right\}$ are close w.r.t. the product topology on $C^{m}$.

Property 13 (Constant-continuity) $\succeq$ is constant-continuous if for all $f \in F$, the better set $\{x \in C: x \succeq f\}$ and the worse set $\{x \in C: x \preceq f\}$ are closed.

Property 14 (Truncation-continuity) $\succeq$ is truncation-continuous if for every $f, g \in \mathcal{F}$ with $f \succ g$, there exists $x, y \in C$ such that $f \nmid x \succ g$ and $f \succ g \nmid y$.

A set of acts is uniformly strongly bounded if there exist $x, y \in C$ such that $x \succeq f(\omega) \succeq y$ for all $\omega \in \Omega$ and acts $f$ in the set.

Property 15 (Bounded-strict-continuity) $\succeq$ is boundedly strictly continuous if for any uniformly bounded sequence of acts $\left(f^{i}\right)_{i=1}^{\infty}$ in $\mathcal{F}$ and any pair of acts $g, h \in \mathcal{F}$ for which $f^{i} \succeq h$ (resp., $f^{i} \preceq h$ ) for all $i$ and $\lim _{i \rightarrow \infty} f^{i}(\omega)=g(\omega)$ for all $\omega \in \Omega$, we have $g \succeq h$ (resp., $g \preceq h)$.

Definition 1 (Countable-Additive Subjective Expected Utility) The preference relation $\succeq$ admits a countable-additive Subjective Expected Utility representation if for all $f, g \in \mathcal{F}$,

$$
f \succeq g
$$

if and only if

$$
\int_{\Omega} u \circ f d \mu \geq \int_{\Omega} u \circ g d \mu
$$

for a continuous utility function $u: C \longrightarrow \mathbb{R}$ and a countable-additive probability measure $\mu \in \Delta(\Omega)$.

If $\Omega$ is simple $\succeq$-null, then $\mu$ is arbitrary and $u$ is constant.
If $\Omega$ is simple $\succeq$-non-null but no two disjoint simple $\succeq$-non-null events exist in $\Sigma_{\Omega}$, then $\mu$ assigns probability 1 to every simple $\succeq$-non-null event and probability 0 to every simple $\succeq$-null event, and $u$ is unique up to continuous strictly increasing transformations.

Otherwise, the utility function is unique up to positive affine transformations and $\mu$ is uniquely determined.

Theorem 3 (Wakker, 1989) Properties 9 to 15 hold if and only if $\succeq$ admits a countable additive subjective expected representation.

See Wakker (1989, Chapter V.5), in particular Theorems V.4.6, V.5.2, and Observation V.3.4'. An even stronger result could be obtained using Wakker (1993).

Kopylov (2010) provides a nice alternative characterization for countable additive subjective expected utility. However, he obtains just non-atomistic probability measures, which does not fit our framework.

Note that by Theorem 3, the Sure Thing Principle must hold: For any event $E \in \Sigma_{\Omega}$ and any $f, g, h, h^{\prime} \in \mathcal{F}$,

$$
f_{E} h \succeq g_{E} h \text { if and only if } f_{E} h^{\prime} \succeq g_{E} h^{\prime}
$$

Thus, we can define for each nonempty $E \in \Sigma_{\Omega}$, a conditional preference relation $\succeq_{E}$ on $\mathcal{F}$ by for $f, g \in \mathcal{F}$,

$$
f \succeq_{E} g \text { if and only if } f_{E} h \succeq g_{E} h
$$

for some $h \in \mathcal{F}$.

Definition 2 We say that $\succeq_{E}$ for nonempty $E \in \Sigma_{\Omega}$ admits a $E$-conditional countable additive subjective expected utility representation when $\succeq$ in Definition 1 is replaced by $\succeq_{E}, \mu$ is replaced by the conditional probability measure $\mu(\cdot \mid E)$, and $u$ is replaced by $u_{E}$.

For event $E \in \Sigma_{\Omega}$ and consequences $x, y, z, w \in C$, write

$$
x y \unrhd_{E} z w
$$

(i.e., subscript $E$ ) if there exists an event $F \in \Sigma_{\Omega}$ and simple acts $f, g \in \mathcal{F}$ such that $x_{F} f \succeq_{E} y_{F} g$ and $z_{F} f \preceq_{E} w_{F} g$.

Property 16 (Risk Invariance) For any events $E, F \in \Sigma_{\Omega}, \unrhd_{E}=\unrhd_{F}$.

Note that above exposition allows $C=\mathbb{R}$. In such a case, it is handy to also consider a very strict notion monotonicity:

Property 17 (Strict monotonicity) Let $C=\mathbb{R} . \succeq$ is strictly monotone if $x, y \in \mathcal{F}, x>y$ if and only if $x \succ y$.

Corollary 4 Let $C=\mathbb{R}$. For any nonempty $E \in \Sigma_{\Omega}, \succeq_{E}$ Properties 9 to 15 if and only if it admits the E-conditional countable additive subjective expected representation. Moreover, $u_{E}$ can be chosen such that $u_{E}=u$ if and only if $\succeq_{E}$ satisfies Property 16. Finally, $u$ is strictly monotone if and only if $\succeq_{E}$ satisfies strict monotonicity.

abstract:
We consider a decision maker who is unaware of objects to be sampled and thus
cannot form beliefs about the occurrence of particular objects. Ex ante she can
form beliefs about the occurrence of novelty and the frequencies of yet to be
known objects. Conditional on any sampled objects, she can also form beliefs
about the next object being novel or being one of the previously sampled
objects. We characterize behaviorally such beliefs under subjective expected
utility. In doing so, we relate "reverse" Bayesianism, a central property in
the literature on decision making under growing awareness, with exchangeable
random partitions, the central property in the literature on the discovery of
species problem and mutations in statistics, combinatorial probability theory,
and population genetics. Partition exchangeable beliefs do not necessarily
satisfy "reverse" Bayesianism. Yet, the most prominent models of exchangeable
random partitions, the model by De Morgan (1838), the one parameter model of
Ewens (1972), and the two parameter model of Pitman (1995) and Zabell (1997),
do satisfy "reverse" Bayesianism. Our characterization allows us to interpret
these models as subjective beliefs of a decision maker and to derive the
parameters from choice behavior.
